posts.name: Brennyn
posts.cooked:
My team is looking at maybe mounting our electronics on the bottom of the bot next year. I’ve seen some team like 6081, and 503 and was wondering how its worked for you guys compared to mounting it facing up. Questions I have about it:

how much pre planning did it take

do you find it easier to wire

how is cable management with it compared to conventional

would you say its easier to work on in the pits

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We have found facing the electronics down to be far superior to placing it on top.  We put our electrical board on top of our frame 2x1s, and then the electrical components face downward.

There is nothing taller than 2",so you can  screw a normal belly pan on.  We use polycarbonate as the belly pan so you can see the components for a quick check.

The real benefits are servicing.  You have easy access to everything, and don’t have to stuff your hands in between various mechanisms to reach stuff.

It is critically important, however, that you label all your wires at each connection point.  Because they travel from top to underneath, they can be impossible to trace quickly… If you have a motor not getting power, you want to be able to flip the robot and know exactly which wire it is plugged into the pdh.

I would say this should always be best practice, but you can get away with a little less care when you can see the whole wire run.

Also, depending on how you terminate your wiring, you can put yourself in a situation where you can’t get the termination (Anderson powerpole for example)  back through the hole for the wire because the termination is bigger than the hole.

All in all, I can’t think of a good reason not to go with inverted electronics.  Make sure you hot glue everything as well.

posts.name: Brennyn
posts.cooked: do you happen to have a picture of your robots board i’m trying to get examples for our electrical team to look at

posts.name: Nishant Amirineni
posts.cooked:
'24 503 alumni here (although I was not on our electrical subteam),

All of our electrical bellypan components had preplanned locations in cad(pdp, rio, etc) this was being done simultaneously with mechanism design, and didnt really impede our workflow.

All of our electrical bellypan components had preplanned locations in cad(pdp, rio, etc) this was being done simultaneously with mechanism design, and didnt really impede our workflow.

Didn’t touch this personally so I can’t answer for certain, but I understand the reason that we originally made the switch in 2022(?) was mainly for ease of access.

Didn’t touch this personally so I can’t answer for certain, but I understand the reason that we originally made the switch in 2022(?) was mainly for ease of access.

Again, cant answer personally, but everything is really easy to access and manage by just popping open the bellypan.

Again, cant answer personally, but everything is really easy to access and manage by just popping open the bellypan.

Again, access is really easy, all it takes is flipping the robot on its side and undoing a few bolts(we also keep a hinge on one side so we can just flip it open).

Again, access is really easy, all it takes is flipping the robot on its side and undoing a few bolts(we also keep a hinge on one side so we can just flip it open).

As @Tom_Line said, labels really help with keeping track of wires as it can be hard to tell what each wire is for once its down in the bellypan space.

One thing to note though is that we have noticed that the rio does not like to stay upside down(if I remember correctly its because some of the ports are really only held in  by gravity). In the past we dealt with this by putting the rio on the hinging bottom bellypan piece right side up, however we decided to stick it above the bellypan space on an empty area on the surface  of the robot on a raised platform for impact resistance, ease of access, and so it wouldnt be on a moving part this year and that worked out pretty well.

Overall we’re pretty happy with at least this portion of how we do our electronics and would recommend others do the same.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Please keep in mind that this might make it harder for the Robot Inspector to do their job, which in turn might cause you delays.  Imagine you’re going through the Inspection Checklist in order , and consider how many times you will have to flip the robot in the process.  Good labels can mitigate this.  Also, if there’s a cover that needs to be removed to do inspection, please remember to remove it before the RI gets to your pit.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked: In many cases upside-down electronics/bellypan actually make inspection much easier since the electrical/pneumatic components aren’t buried under all the robot mechanisms and hard to access. Face-down underneath makes it much more accessible and visible- good for maintenance and inspection. The couple of times my former team has done it in the past, we usually only had to flip the robot once for inspection.

posts.name: WillCaradonna
posts.cooked:
image 1920×2560 649 KB image 720×405 70.3 KB

image 1920×2560 649 KB

image 1920×2560 649 KB

image 720×405 70.3 KB

image 720×405 70.3 KB

1. how much pre planning did it take We would plan it out if it was conventional, this makes it easier to plan, as we don’t need to account for any of the sub systems above, only the swerve modules/ robot structure. We also countersink the bolts on our inverted bellypan to keep the top flat is there is a sub system up there. This also allows us to mount stuff on the top of the belly pan as well. Which is where we put the PIs on our '24 robot.

2. do you find it easier to wire Yes, as it prevents the need to wire around subsystems, it also allows us to work quicker at competitions as our electronics are fully exposed once we removed the polycarbonate cover panel

3. how is cable management with it compared to conventional About the same, we continue to label all the connections to help with diagnostics

4. would you say its easier to work on in the pits Yes, especially with the smaller robots. In '23 we tried to do a hybrid electrical panel, with 2 upward facing and 1 inverted to make it easier for the FTA to see the RoboRio, and the upward facing compartments were almost unserviceable

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
I love a good inverted electrical board, save kids’ hands from being cut/scrapped.

Three things to watch out for.

If you need a really tall super structure (like most robots in 2018 or 2022) it gets unwieldy in the pits.

The pin connectors can get real finicky and either don’t use them or use something to secure them (hot glue, 3d print, VHB tape, etc…).

If you are using a practice bot, make sure all of the sensors are mounted in the same ordination.  We once were using an NavX and the roborio was flipped one bot but not the other…

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
kingbrandon14:

In many cases upside-down electronics/bellypan actually make inspection much easier since the electrical/pneumatic components aren’t buried under all the robot mechanisms and hard to access.

I don’t disagree that, once any covers have been removed, this can make the electronics more inspectable.  I’ve certainly seen non-inverted setups where the PDP / PDH was hidden under a mechanism or had other electronics stuck on top of it that made it very hard to inspect.  I’m just trying to point out a couple of avoidable inspection problems that an inverted setup might introduce.

As a specific example of potential issues with an inverted setup, the RI must trace the power wiring for the roboRIO [1] , the radio [2] , PCM /PH [3] , and any linear actuators [4] .  If this wiring passes through holes in the belly pan, then each trace potentially requires two flips.  A few minutes with a labeller can make inspection much more efficient.

roboRIO is restricted to 10A on an unswitched fused channel. ↩︎

roboRIO is restricted to 10A on an unswitched fused channel. ↩︎

I am hopeful that radio power problems will be far less common with the new radios, but there are still ways to connect it wrongly, and I anticipate that there will still be a current restriction on the circuit so the fuse/breaker will still need to be checked. ↩︎

I am hopeful that radio power problems will be far less common with the new radios, but there are still ways to connect it wrongly, and I anticipate that there will still be a current restriction on the circuit so the fuse/breaker will still need to be checked. ↩︎

PCM /PH is restricted to 20A fuse or breaker and is the only circumstance under which a PDH fused channel can exceed 15A. ↩︎

PCM /PH is restricted to 20A fuse or breaker and is the only circumstance under which a PDH fused channel can exceed 15A. ↩︎

Linear actuators are restricted to 20A breaker regardless of wire gauge. ↩︎

Linear actuators are restricted to 20A breaker regardless of wire gauge. ↩︎

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
These show essentially all electronics plus a pneumatics system in a swerve drive base.  Use of CAD was pretty helpful, but doing a mock-up on a sheet of cardboard could also work.  We used low-profile screws to mount everything to a 1/4" sheet of polycarb, and a RIO 1.0 (running C++, to avoid the removable storage thing).

In addition to ease of access, everything is behind the bumpers – protected – and there’s a lot of weight that’s really low. PXL_20230225_195147449 1920×2560 523 KB PXL_20230225_200107082 1920×2560 446 KB

posts.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
posts.cooked:
I have to jump in here with a few caveats.

Please protect electronics that are mounted upside down.  Frequently robots run over debris on the field that will take out critical components.

Be sure everything is tight.  I have seen breakers fall out, connectors on the Rio, etc.

Your design may or may not make inspections difficult but upside down usually makes diagnosing problems very hard.

Please follow the instructions for using and mounting the radio.  Under the chassis is the last place you want that critical device.

Make sure everything is secure, you don’t want to be dragging around the Rio, or motor controllers or even the PDP / PDH while driving.

All electrical rules and practices apply regardless of orientation.

We have mounted electronics under the chassis on occasion, after considering all pros and cons.  One year, the cover was added as ballast to keep COG low.  Your mileage will vary.
posts.display_username: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Chief Robot Inspector   Learn Something New, Ever Day!

posts.custom_user_title: Chief Robot Inspector   Learn Something New, Ever Day!

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Al_Skierkiewicz:

Be sure everything is tight. I have seen breakers fall out…

Speaking of this, I discovered that it is possible to insert your breakers with their connection tabs on the outside of the connector in the PDH .  I discovered this when I found a breaker that was so very wobbly when the rest were quite firm.  I suspect if the PDH was mounted upside down, it would have fallen right out in motion (which might have been a good thing – turning a confusing intermittent issue into an immediately apparent issue – as long as it happened in practice, anyway).

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
This happened to us at championships, luckily on our climbing brake motor, with the REV breakers in the REV PDH .  The motor was working until it wasn’t.  Saw that the motor controller was not powered.  Tracing back to the PDH , noticed that the breaker was a little crooked and wobbly.

It clicked right away what had happened and it was so funny.  I had to shout over for our rookie pit student who had placed the breaker to show them and they received a little light ribbing about it.  I take some blame for not checking their work.  So now we know that it isn’t hard to do and that you have to make sure you are feeling some resistance to pushing the breaker in and that they aren’t crooked or wobbly.

edit:  I think inverted boards are a great idea though we haven’t done many  (2021 mainly).  It would generally be easier to work on if the robot lays down on one side reasonably well.  Some robots are hard to work on with all the electronics in the bellypan with plenty in the way.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
